document_content.title: Referral to Endocrinology for Evaluation of Newly Diagnosed Hyperthyroidism

sections.heading: Reason for Referral
sections.content: Ms. Jane Doe is being referred to your endocrinology clinic for further evaluation and management of recently diagnosed hyperthyroidism. She presented with symptoms suggestive of thyrotoxicosis, which have not resolved with initial supportive care.

sections.heading: History of Present Illness
sections.content: The patient reports a six-week history of increasing fatigue, unintentional weight loss of 4 kg, palpitations, and occasional tremors. She has also experienced increased sweating and heat intolerance. There is no history of neck pain or swelling, and she denies any visual changes or difficulty swallowing. No previous thyroid issues are documented.

sections.heading: Assessment
sections.content: Laboratory evaluation revealed suppressed TSH (<0.01 mIU/L), elevated free T4 and T3 levels. Physical examination found a fine tremor and mild tachycardia (pulse 104 bpm), but no goiter or ophthalmopathy. No evidence of cardiac arrhythmia or heart failure.

sections.heading: Plan
sections.content: Requesting your expertise for further diagnostic workup, including consideration of thyroid antibody testing and thyroid imaging. Beta-blocker therapy (propranolol 20 mg BID) has been initiated for symptomatic relief. Please advise on definitive management options, including antithyroid medications or possible radioactive iodine therapy as indicated.
